content: The Act may be cited as the "Responsible Consumer Financial Protection Regulations Act of 2011" and establishes the Commission. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 amends Section 1011 by establishing a Commission to serve as the head of the Bureau with the authority to prescribe regulations and issue orders for carrying out laws within its jurisdiction. The Commission established under the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is composed of the Vice Chairman for Supervision of the Federal Reserve System and 4 additional members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members must be U.S. citizens with expertise in consumer financial protection and a commitment to safeguarding service members and their families from financial exploitation. The Commission established under the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 consists of the Vice Chairman for Supervision of the Federal Reserve System and 4 members appointed by the President for terms of 1, 2, 4, and 5 years. Members serve for 5 years and can only be removed for specific reasons. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the term. The Commission members appointed under the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 can continue to serve after their term expires until a successor is appointed. They are prohibited from engaging in other employment. One member is responsible for overseeing the Bureau's activities. The designated commissioner oversees the Bureau's activities in protecting consumers, particularly older, minorities, youth, and veterans, from unfair lending practices. Responsibilities include conducting outreach to consumers, researching and reporting on new loan products' impact, and coordinating with State-level agencies for consumer protection enforcement. The Chair of the Commission, appointed by the President from among the members, is the principal executive officer of the Bureau, responsible for all executive and administrative functions including personnel appointment and business distribution. The Chair of the Commission, appointed by the President, is responsible for personnel appointment, business distribution, and fund use. The Chair must adhere to Commission policies and regulatory decisions. Requests for appropriations must be approved by the Commission. The Commission's operations are not impaired by vacancies in its members. A quorum of three members is required for business transactions, but if vacancies reduce the members to three or two, a quorum can be formed accordingly. The Commission must have an official seal. The Chair of the Commission receives compensation at a specified rate. The Commission's operations are not affected by vacancies in its members. A quorum of three members is needed for transactions, but can be adjusted if vacancies reduce the members. The Chair of the Commission receives compensation at a specified rate, with other members receiving compensation at a different rate. SEC. 3. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 is amended in various sections by replacing terms like "Director" with "Commission of the Bureau" and "Assistant Director" with "Head of the Office." The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is amended to replace "Director" with "Chair of the Commission" and "Director of the Bureau" with "Bureau" in specific sections. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act and Expedited Funds Availability Act are also amended in a similar manner. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act, Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978, and Financial Literacy and Education Improvement Act are amended to replace references to the "Director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau" with "Chair of the Commission of the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection".
